channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Low-Income US Families Face Growing Gap Between Earnings, Costs
item.description: There’s a growing gap between what low-income families earn and what it actually costs to live in the US, according to a new study that says headline measures of inflation fail to capture the burden on these households.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Nazmul Ahasan

item.title: US, China to Slash Tariffs in Step Back from Decoupling Brink
item.description: The US and China will temporarily lower tariffs on each other’s products in a dramatic ratcheting down of trade tensions that buys the world’s two largest economies three months to work toward a broader agreement.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, right, and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer in Geneva on May 12. Photographer: Jean-Christophe Bott/AP Photo

item.title: IMF Plans Kenya Debt Scrutiny to Weigh Funding Needs in New Deal
item.description: The International Monetary Fund plans an in-depth review of Kenya’s debt to determine the nation’s financing needs under a new program.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

item.title: ECB to Cut by More as Inflation Undershoots 2%, Poll Shows
item.description: The European Central Bank will lower borrowing costs more than previously expected this year to below 2% as inflation is seen undershooting the institution’s target in early 2026, according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: SNB’s Brief Era of Positive Rates May Be About to End
item.description: The Swiss National Bank will probably cut its interest rate to zero in June after less than three years in positive territory, according to a Bloomberg survey.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: Global Stocks Climb After US, China Agree to Cut Tariffs for 90 Days
Japan’s Merchants’ Mood Hits Worst in Three Years on Tariff Woes
item.description: Sentiment among Japanese merchants sank to the lowest in more than three years, underscoring deepening concerns over the economic outlook at home and abroad as the impact from US tariffs begins to filter into the economy.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Cherry trees in bloom in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Japan's cabinet office will release a monthly consumer confidence survey on April 9.

item.title: US and China Tout Progress in Trade Talks, Offer Few Details
item.description: The US and China both reported “substantial progress” after two days of talks in Switzerland aimed at de-escalating a trade war, marking what Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng called “an important first step” toward resolving differences.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Hugo Miller

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, left, and Jamieson Greer after talks between US and Chinese officials in Geneva on May 11.

item.title: Swedes’ Housing Optimism Weakens With Lower Consumer Confidence
item.description: Optimism among Swedes over the direction of home prices is waning as the Nordic country continues to grapple with economic headwinds and the prospect of slowing growth.
item.dc:creator: Charles Daly

item.title: Africa’s Eswatini Kingdom Plans $275 Million Wealth Fund
item.description: The southern African Kingdom of Eswatini plans to start a sovereign wealth fund of around 5 billion emalangeni ($275 million) this year to help channel money into areas including manufacturing and agriculture, its finance minister said.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: Neal Rijkenberg Photographer: Jemal Countess/Global Citizen

item.title: Japan Rules Out Trade Deal With US That Excludes Auto Tariffs
item.description: Japan won’t accept any initial trade agreement with the US that excludes an accord on autos, according to Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Americans Embrace Road Trips as Economic Fears Discourage Flying
item.description: Kristin Herman and her partner had been planning a European getaway with stops in Paris and Rome, but with the US economy suddenly wobbling, the couple instead drove to Oregon’s nearby redwood forests and Cannon Beach — even camping some nights to save on hotels.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: Traffic moves along Interstate 80 in Emeryville, California, US, on Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024. AAA projects 79.9 million travelers will head 50 miles or more from home over the Thanksgiving holiday travel period. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Bank Deposits Rise at Slowest Since ’07 as Inflation Bites
item.description: Japan’s bank deposits increased at the slowest pace since April 2007 as households seek to safeguard their assets from inflation.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: Japan’s Sputtering Economy Likely Stalled Before Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Japan’s economy likely suffered a contraction in the first three months of this year, signaling underlying fragility even before US tariff measures started hitting the country in earnest, according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: US-China Trade Talks to Boost Sentiment in Asia, Strategists Say
item.description: “Substantial progress” made in US-China trade relations after two days of talks in Switzerland is likely to boost sentiment in Asia, according to some strategists, while others were awaiting further details.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess, Carmeli Argana, Mia Glass, Momoka Yokoyama, Alice French

item.title: US Ambassador Says Canada Tariffs May Not Be ‘Totally Removed’
item.description: Some US tariffs on Canadian imports may remain in place even as the relationship between the two countries improves, Peter Hoekstra, the US ambassador to Canada, said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Dobby

media:content.media:description: 米国のホークストラ駐カナダ大使

item.title: US Inflation Starting to Stir as Trump Tariff Threat Looms
item.description: US consumer prices probably picked up in April after the smallest advance in nine months, foreshadowing a broader acceleration as many companies seek to pass on higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, April 15, 2025. Consumer sentiment has turned uneasy amid concern about tariffs, though retail sales aren’t likely to show any pullback in March as consumers continued front-loading purchases of goods and cars ahead of possible tariff-driven price hikes.

item.title: Traders Eye Longer-Term Options to Hedge Post-Tariff Shock Rally
item.description: As April’s volatility storm fades into memory, traders are left balancing calmer markets and the ever-present risk of a fresh round of headline shocks.
item.dc:creator: Christian Dass

media:content.media:description: A VIX chart displayed on a monitor on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Federal Reserve officials held interest rates steady for a third-straight meeting and emphasized they see a growing risk of both higher inflation and rising unemployment.

item.title: Trump Hails Progress as US-China Negotiators Resume Trade Talks
item.description: Senior US and Chinese negotiators resumed on Sunday high-stakes talks to de-escalate their trade war, with President Donald Trump calling the hours-long discussions held a day earlier a “very good” meeting.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Enda Curran

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent leaves his hotel to a meeting with China's officials on tariffs in Geneva, on May 10.

item.title: Trump Says ‘Much Agreed to’ in Meeting With Chinese Officials
item.description: President Donald Trump said US and Chinese negotiators in Switzerland had “a very good meeting” in an effort to de-escalate their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Chelsea Mes

item.title: ECB’s Vujcic Expects Inflation to Slow to 2% Target by Year-End
item.description: Consumer-price growth will hit the European Central Bank’s 2% target by the end of 2025, according to Governing Council member Boris Vujcic.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Kuzmanovic

media:content.media:description: Boris Vujcic, governor of the Croatian National Bank, during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Ten Years Of Euro In Latvia conference in Riga, Latvia on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024. The conference brings policy makers, experts and civil society representatives who played a pivotal role in the introduction of the euro all across Europe and specifically in Latvia.

item.title: UK Chancellor Reeves Set to Review ISAs Within Weeks, FT Reports
item.description: The UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves is preparing to launch a review of the market for Individual Savings Accounts within weeks, the Financial Times reported Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Gabriela Mello

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, during a news conference following her presentation of the Spring Statement in London, UK, on Wednesday, March 26, 2025. Reeves clawed back £14 billion ($18 billion) worth of fiscal room with cuts to welfare and government spending, after the UK’s growth forecast for the current year was cut in half. Photographer: Andy Rain/EPA

item.title: Decoupling Threatens China’s Enduring Interest in US Capital
item.description: In the US, Chinese insurance broker Yuanbao Inc. isn’t a household name on Main Street. It’s unlikely to be known by many on Wall Street, either.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

media:content.media:description: USED: New York, San Francisco - Feb. 1, 2019
